About KB-NEAT, it might be useful for poker.  Ryan Cornelius is the 
one wh=
o coded KB-NEAT, and he even had it working on blackjack, I 
believe.  But =
I don't think he ever released the code.  I could 
probably put you in touc=
h with his email address if you want and 
maybe he'd help out.  If you're i=
nterested please send me an email.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "tan=
sey4" <tansey4@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm a grad student at Virginia =
Tech and I would like to enter a bot
> into the AAAI poker competition in J=
uly.  I've been working on 
poker
> AI in my spare time for the last 3 year=
s.  I've looked at a lot of 
the
> Alberta group's work and talked to most =
of them at last year's AAAI
> competition.
> 
> My general plan is to use K=
B-NEAT and a set of controllers + 
variables
> to evolve a network for rapi=
d player modeling and exploitation in
> limit (and possibly no-limit) Hold =
Em.
> 
> A lot of the knowledge in poker is very explicit with little
> exc=
eptions.  For instance, "cap with the nut flush" (i.e. never 
stop
> raisin=
g) is a perfect example of a piece of advice that works in 
80%
> of cases,=
 but certain situations, like the board being paired,
> invalidate that adv=
ice.  I hope to help kick-start the learning
> process by developing a fair=
ly in-depth set of advice rules.
> 
> My bot will also deviate from the nor=
mal approach of game_state ->
> atomic action (e.g., fold/call/raise).  Ins=
tead I'm going to have 
the
> bot select a "play" at the start of each roun=
d.  I define a play 
as a
> set of betting actions that handle any case in =
the current round.  
An
> example post-flop play (from first position) woul=
d be
> Check-Raise-Call.  Here, there is no way that the bot could ever 
re=
ach
> a situation where it doesn't know what to do.
> 
> I chose to use pla=
ys for two reasons.  First, they simplify the 
input
> to the network as yo=
u do not have to consider the sequence of 
bets. 
> Second, I believe that =
most (non-novice) human players actually 
use a
> similar--or even higher l=
evel-- model when playing.  For instance,
> good players no-limit players (=
and to a lesser extent, limit 
players)
> will often play a single hand in =
a loose fashion (usually 
attempting a
> large bluff), hoping that the next=
 hand will give them a similar
> situation but with a legitimate hand.  In =
such cases, players are
> actually planning on making the bluffs and subseq=
uent big hands 
well
> ahead of time.  The evidence for this should be the =
speed with 
which
> most limit ring games are played.  As the stakes rise, =
the speed of
> the game tends to increase, as players create more abstract =
plays.
> 
> The inputs for my networks will be broken down into three main
=
> categories: betting, stats, and history.  Betting will simply be a
> repr=
esenation of the previous rounds' bet history.  Stats will
> encompass thin=
gs like hand strength vs a random player, flush draw
> probability, etc.
> =

> History will be a set of player statistics broken into 3
> sub-categorie=
s: total, previous hand, and a variable range.  The
> statistics for each c=
ategory will all be the same, with only the
> sample size varying.  Total w=
ill encompass the entire play history 
of
> the opponent.  Previous hand wi=
ll look only at the previous hand. 
> Variable range will use the play over=
 the previous N hands (where 
N <
> 30).  This way I hope to be able to mod=
el players that quickly 
change
> their play.
> 
> I have a few questions:
=
> 
> 1) Is there a way I can use multiple networks per individual in the
> =
population?  I.e., I want to have a separate network for each 
round,
> sin=
ce there are different inputs (cards, bets) for each successive
> round.  I=
 have considered making one monolithic network and using
> extra nodes to r=
epresent on/off status of the round-specific data, 
but
> I feel like that =
would add a lot of needless noise to the network.
> 
> 2) This is related t=
o 1, but is there any way to also encorporate
> other variables in my evolu=
tion parameters?
> 
> 3) Is there any code available for the KB-NEAT so I c=
an 
incorporate my
> custom advice?
> 
> 
> If anyone is interested in a mo=
re detailed description of the 
inputs,
> let me know.
> 
> 
> Wesley
>
